docs.title: Welcome!
docs.text:
Welcome to the Puzzle Makers Wiki! Our goal is to be a useful resource for designing and analyzing Twisty Puzzles. This site is a collaboration between members of the Puzzle Makers Discord. We are not directly affiliated with the Twisty Puzzles Forum, though of course there is a lot of overlap.

This wiki is split into three major sections.

docs.title: Theory
docs.text: Puzzle Theory deals in the mathematical analysis of twisty puzzles. Some topics include Grip Theory, applications of Group Theory, and the study of Monodihedrals

docs.title: Design
docs.text: The aim of the Design section is to provide resources so that anyone may design their own twisty puzzles. Some topics include strategies for choosing axis systems, Intro to CAD, and tutorials for advanced puzzle making techniques, such as Hyperbolic Cuts and shell puzzles.

docs.title: Production
docs.text: The Production section helps bring puzzle designs to life. Some topics include choosing a 3d printer, choosing good print orientations, and tips for post processing.

docs.title: Contributing
docs.text:
WORK IN PROGRESS

Contibuting to this wiki should be as easy and accessible as possible. I have not had a chance to write a proper guide and test everything. For now, this page requires a bit of know-how and only lists the bare minimum info to get started.

In order to contribute to this wiki, you will need to have Python and Git installed.

  • Use Git to clone the Puzzle Makers Wiki Repo
  • Use your choice of python package manager (ex, pip) to install the dependencies found in requirements.txt
  • Use mkdocs serve to host the page locally and see your changes immediately
  • When you're done making changes, put in a pull request!

docs.title: Glossary
docs.text:
Below you will find a handy list of terms frequently used by the twisty puzzle community. Not all terms are well defined, with several having multiple overlapping definitions.

Doctrinaire
  • A puzzle in which all possible states are identical when coloration (Stickers, tiles, etc) are removed.
  • "a puzzle whose state space can be represented by a finite permutation group with a fixed set of generators"

docs.title: Hyperbolic Cuts
docs.text:
Hyperbolic Cuts refer to cutting surfaces created using Hyperboloids. They are a form of non-planar cut that can be used to give puzzles unique face patterns or to hide certain piece types.

Hyperbolic cuts can be used to hide the face centers of a Compy Cube (left) in order to create a Redi Cube (right).

docs.title: Construction
docs.text:
Typical construction of a hyperbolic cut puzzle involves the following steps:

  • Creating a base cutting surface for target puzzle
  • Drawing desired cut shape on a face adjacent to cutting surface
  • Revolving cut shape around same axis of rotation as base cutting surface (This creates a Hyperboloid)
  • Splitting the hyperboloid and incorporating its shape into the cutting surface
  • Revolving, Patterning, and Splitting the puzzle as normal, with newly designed hyperbolic cutting surface

An example of a Hyperboloid produced in the process of creating a Redi Cube.

Hyperbolic cuts can lead to strange geometry that may be difficult to fillet during the finishing steps.
